formattedAddress: 30 W 35th St, New York, NY 10001, USA
adrFormatAddress: 30 W 35th St, New York, NY 10001, USA

editorialSummary.text: Straightforward Latin American take-out spot specializing in build-your-own gourmet arepas.

originalText.text: Got the Pepito and the Pepiada, as they were recommended as the most popular items. Like others have commented here, they tend to be on the dry side. The box was a bit messy and eating them requires napkins. But overall pretty decent for the price. Had leftovers after lunch that lasted a few days. But the dryness really sets the arepas back

text.text: Got the Pepito and the Pepiada, as they were recommended as the most popular items. Like others have commented here, they tend to be on the dry side. The box was a bit messy and eating them requires napkins. But overall pretty decent for the price. Had leftovers after lunch that lasted a few days. But the dryness really sets the arepas back

originalText.text:
Extremely dry steak, nowhere near enough moisture to even out the dryness of the arepa, flavor was lacking... BUT the fried chicken's texture was excellent.

It took like, 20 minutes to get these arepas even though there was nobody in front of us in line. The guy at the window cam back to us after 10 minutes to manually write down our orders after we paid. Literally why?

Also EXTREMELY expensive for what you get. You can get more for less at other places.

text.text:

It took like, 20 minutes to get these arepas even though there was nobody in front of us in line. The guy at the window cam back to us after 10 minutes to manually write down our orders after we paid. Literally why?

Also EXTREMELY expensive for what you get. You can get more for less at other places.

originalText.text: AMAZING! Just tried as a first time customer and I am in love with these arepas!  I ordered the El Che.  Filling, fully packed in with meat and fillings and an amazing chimichurri sauce, can't believe this is my first time coming here, definitely won't be the last! Will tell everyone to come, the quality here is fantastic!

text.text: AMAZING! Just tried as a first time customer and I am in love with these arepas!  I ordered the El Che.  Filling, fully packed in with meat and fillings and an amazing chimichurri sauce, can't believe this is my first time coming here, definitely won't be the last! Will tell everyone to come, the quality here is fantastic!

originalText.text:
I need to preface this review by saying I am Hispanic and have higher expectations for this kind of food. That being said, the arepas were quite dry, and the flavor of the asada was lacking. All in all edible, but I would not eat it again.

Maybe pay as much attention to the quality of the food as you have to the packaging, and you might get more stars

text.text:
I need to preface this review by saying I am Hispanic and have higher expectations for this kind of food. That being said, the arepas were quite dry, and the flavor of the asada was lacking. All in all edible, but I would not eat it again.

Maybe pay as much attention to the quality of the food as you have to the packaging, and you might get more stars

originalText.text:
Easy-to-miss hole in the wall next to Barn Joo. If you look only at the scaffolding and the surrounding enclosures for dining, it is too easy to miss Costas, and that is a shame.
They offer arepas, both build your own and with pre-made selections. The premades feature flavors from non-traditional additions like French fries and coleslaw, since their Modus operandi is to unite and bridge cultures through arepas. It is ambitious and often difficult. However, they manage to achieve some great bites.
I ordered the Francois and Mrs. Cheng, the respectively French and Asian inspired arepas. The François comes with beef and Pommes frites while Mrs. Cheng has a fried cutlet with sauce reminiscent of Peking duck, and slaw. They also had sancocho stew that my friend ordered and I had some.
The arepa dough is masa, first and foremost, and you can smell a slight sweetness from the corn. They make them fresh and so the wait is a bit longer. The texture is crumbly compared to wheat flour because it is gluten-free.
The Francois was decent. Unfortunately, I felt it was lacking in flavor, though there was a generous portion of meat. There was no flavor from the potatoes, which could have used some salt. The peppercorn sauce didn't really taste of anything.
Mrs. Cheng was much better in terms of flavor, with strong sweet and slightly tangy notes. The meat was thin and fried so it can feel a bit tough. The slaw and sauce help to make it not too dry. It's messier to eat, but it was good.
The sancocho stew was filled with meat, avocado, and came with rice. It was piping hot and great for a cold day. The thickness was decent. However, I felt it was underseasoned and lacking in some spice or salt.
Overall, this is a nice hidden place to pick up some unique food. They do not have seating, so all food is pretty much take out. Their packaging is fun. The price is also not bad for two arepas considering the price of other ethnic foods in the area.
